COAL MINING.Employment in the coal mining industry has remained slack on the whole since the beginning of the year. During March an appreciable increase in the number of miners temporarily stopped from work was reported. This is stated to be due to a shortage of orders.IRON AND STEEL.A considerable improvement in the iron and steel trades took place during January. This was maintained during the two succeeding months although the rate of recovery was not so rapid. The employment position at the end of March is considerably better than it was a year ago. In the tinplate and pig-iron industries a substantial improvement has also been shown, unemployment in the former being 8*1 per cent, less than a year ago.SHIPBUILDING AND SHIP-REPAIRING.Unemployment in the shipbuilding and ship-repairing industry has fallen by about 30,000 since the beginning of the year. While a considerable part of this reduction was doubtless due to work on orders which were held up during the strike, the prospects in this industry are stated to be fairly satisfactory. The amount of tonnage under construction at the end of March is appreciably in excess of that being built at the end of December.ENGINEERING.During the quarter fairly consistent improvement has been shown in all branches of engineering except in the electrical section in which unemployment is slightly greater than at the end of the previous quarter. Compared with a year ago the Marine branch has made the most marked recovery, unemployment being 5'2 per cent, lower.TEXTILES.Cotton. The improvement in the cotton position which began towards the end of last year was maintained throughout the quarter, unemployment at the end of March being appreciably lower than at the corresponding date of last year. Some uncertainty exists, however, as to future prospects.Woollen and Worsted. There was a slight decline in employment in this branch during January, but the position improved and was better in the two succeeding months.Other Textiles. Generally speaking, the improvement which was shown in other branches of the textile trades during the previous quarter has been niain-tained. The hosiery branch is the only one in which unemployment is higher than it was a year ago.BUILDING. BRICK AND TILE MANUFACTURE.In the first two months of the year the normal improvement in this industry was retarded somewhat by a shortage of constructional material. During Maroh, however, an appreciable improvement took place. CLOTHING TRADES.The usual seasonal improvement in these trades occurred during March, and the position compares favourably with a year ago.POTTERY.Employment in this industry continued to improve during the quarter, the biggest advance being made in March.TRANSPORT, DOCK LABOUR AND SHIPPING SERVICES.Apart from employment at the docks, there was a slight all-round improvement in these services during the quarter. In dock labour, however, no appreciable improvement was shown. III. WORK INSTITUTED FOR RELIEF OF UNEMPLOYMENT.Numbers Employed.[See note on page 1 of November 1924 Report (CP. 541 (24)).]The table which follows has been prepared to show, so far as information is available, the number of men employed on works instituted, with financial assistance from the Exchequer or the Road Eund, for the relief of unemployment.Scope of Table. The schemes included are those undertaken by Local and other Authorities and Public Companies with a financial contribution from the State with the object of relieving unemployment; certain schemes gut in hand by Government Departments for the same purpose; and works in respect of which guarantees have been given under the Trade Facilities Acts as capital undertakings calculated to promote employment in this country. Schemes to which State financial assistance is given, but which are not undertaken primarily for the relief of unemployment (e.g., Housing Schemes), and works put in hand by Local Authorities without State assistance are not included. Certain other schemes involving Government assistance are also excluded in view of the impracticability of ascertaining the exact number of men who are directly provided with employment thereby; these include the Export Credits Scheme and contracts for equipment, clothing, &c, accelerated by Government Contracting Departments.Method of Compilation. The figures for the Road and Bridge Schemes assisted by the Ministry of Transport and for schemes assisted by the Unemployment Grants Committee are (with the exception of certain road schemes in respect of which returns are received direct by the Ministry of Transport) obtained from returns received at Employment Exchanges from Local and other Authorities and Public Companies. Those relating to schemes assisted under the Trade Facilities Acts are compiled by the Trade Facilities Act Advisory Committee from returns received from Companies to whom guarantees under the Acts have been given. In the case of the remaining works the figures are compiled or estimated by the Departments mentioned.Works assisted by Number of Men employed at Mar. 26,1927. Feb. 26,1927. (Colonial Office.)Under the Empire Settlement Act, 1922 (an Act to make better provision for furthering British settlement in His Majesty's Oversea Dominions), various schemes have been agreed with Dominion Authorities. This Act, as its title implies, is not one of the Government measures designed to deal with unemployment, and should not be so regarded. It should be borne in mind that the excess of the total outward over the total inward movement from this country is somewhat less than 100,000 a year, and therefore small in comparison with the natural increase of population which for many years before and after the war has not been much less than 400,000 a year.The number of persons approved for assistance and the number of departures during the months of January, February and March, 1927 (with the corresponding figures for the year 1926), and for the twelve months ended the 31st March, 1927 and 1926, respectively, are set out in the following Table: Quarterly Progress Return relating to Schemes approved under " The Empire Settlement Act, 1922."Approval and Departure Figures.____Dominion.Number of Approvals.Month of January.1927. 1926February.1927. 1926.March.1927. 1926.Twelve Months ended March 31.1927. 1926.Number of Departures.Month of-January.1927.1 1926.feburary. Unemployment Insurance.(Estimates, Class V, Vote 7.)The National Insurance Act of 1911 provided Insurance against unemployment in certain selected industries. It was followed by the Act of 1916, which increased the numbers of persons insured, and, in 1920, by an Act of general scope which applied compulsory Insurance against unemployment to 12,000,000 persons. Subsequent amending Acts modified the conditions of receipt of benefit, increased contributions, provided benefit in respect of dependants, and authorised the Treasury to make advances out of the Consolidated Fund up to a limit of 30,000,000.By the Unemployment Insurance (No. 2) Act, 1924, the rates of benefit were raised (from 15s.) to 18s. a week for men, and (from 12s.) to 15s. a week for women, with 2s. (instead of Is.) a week for each young dependent child. Until the 30th June, 1926, since extended by the Act of 1926 to the 31st December, 1927, benefit in respect of contributions may be paid for 26 weeks in a benefit year, while benefit, irrespective of contributions, may be paid during unemployment subject to the satisfaction of special conditions. The Act also amends the disqualification for benefit in the case of persons affected by trade disputes, and it abolishes the right to a refund of contributions at the age of 60, subject to the payment of compensation for the los? of refund rights in certain cases.Statement of Income and Expenditure from Armistice to March 26, 1927.Expenditure Benefit paid .... .... .... 292,761,000Appropriation for Administration .... 28,145,000Section 9 Unemployment Insurance Act (No. 2;, 1924, and Section 25-Unemployment Insurance Act, 1920 2,901,000 Miscellaneous Refunds, &c..... .... .... 1,717,000Interest (Net) ... .... .... 143,000- 325,667,000Income Contributions Employers .... .... .... 108,781,000Employed .... .... 98,023,000Exchequer ............. 73,911,000Exchequer (for ex-Service Men) .... 3,736,000Balance of Old Fund at Armistice (excluding Interest accrued) * Employers .... .... .... 5,825,000Employed .... .... .... 5,825,000Exchequer .... .... .... 3,884,000H - 15,534,000Loans from Treasury (Net)..., .... .... 24,710,000Miscellaneous Deposits in respect of future Contribu-tions, &c..... ............ 972,000325,667,000284,451,000* Norn.-The old Fund at November 8th, 1920, had reached a total of 22,210,000.Estimate of Benefit payable from Armistice to March 31, 1928, 836,870,000. Land Settlement.In England and Wales the provision of small holdings under the Land Settle-ment (Facilities) Act, 1919, and other Land Settlement Schemes for the benefit primarily of ex-Service men, are carried out (a) through the agency of County Councils and Councils of County Boroughs and (&) through the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries.Settlement through Local Authorities. The net capital cost of these schemes up to the 31st March, 1926, when the Land Settlement Scheme came to an end, is estimated to be 15,250,000, of which approximately 14,050,000 (net) was loaned by the Public Works Loan Board. Interest in respect of such loans is payable by Councils. Under Section 26 of the Land Settlement (Facilities) Act, 1919, the Exchequer bears the loss incurred up to the 31st March, 1926, on the Councils' Small Holdings account (e.g., due to charging a fair as opposed to an economic rent), so far as such loss had been reasonably and necessarily incurred.As from the 1st April, 1926, the Exechequer assistance takes the form of annual contributions to meet the difference between the loan charges and the estimated net income from the Councils' estates. These contributions will not commence until the year 1927-28 and their total capitalized value cannot at present be estimated.In Scotland land settlement is not conducted through the agency of County Councils.Ministry's Settlements. Since the Armistice a number of properties have been acquired, and the capital expenditure thereon and the difference, if any, between the annual cost of maintaining and administering them and the rents received from small holders is being borne by the Exchequer. Juveniles.After the Armistice, Juvenile Unemployment Centres were opened in certain localities to deal with the problem of unemployed juveniles. Alter a period of closure centres were again established, and the cost, which was originally shared by the Board of Education and Local Authorities, was, from the 1st April, 1923, to the 31st March, 1924, partly met out of Relief of Unemployment Vote by grants up to 75 per cent, in respect of approved schemes, the Local Authority providing the remaining 25 per cent. From the 1st April, 1924, the Exchequer Grant was, as an emergency measure, for so long as unemployment amongst juveniles remains acute, raised to 100 per cent, of the approved out-of-pocket expenses of Local Education Authorities.From the 1st April, 1926, the Exchequer Grant was revised as follows: (1.) To Authorities in whose areas the average rate of unemployment among insured juveniles exceeded 6 per cent, dxvring the twelve months which ended on the 23rd November, 1925.A per capita grant fixed by the Minister for each Authority separately equal to the approved average weekly cost to the Authority of each Juvenile in average attendance, taking into account recurrent expenditure only, during the twelve months which ended on the 30th June, 30th September, or 31st December, 1925, whichever was the latest period for which consecutive claims had been received. If complete figures for one year ending on one of the above dates were not available, or if the Authority had not previously opened Centres, the per capita grant was fixed by the Minister on such information, including the Authority's proposals for 1926/27, as was available to him.(2.)
